Award.AwardTitle: BPR: Increasing STEM Participation and Success Rates of Latino Youth Using Culturally Relevant Immersive Technologies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The CREST-funded Cyber-ShARE Center of Excellence, a center focused on advancing research and education through cyberinfrastructures in support of interdisciplinary efforts, serves as the anchor for the project, Increasing STEM Participation and Success Rates of Latino Youth Using Culturally Relevant Immersive Technologies. The goal of the proposed work is to study the effectiveness of augmenting STEM-integrated learning modules with culturally relevant, immersive technologies and determine its impact on Latino middle school students' performance in STEM and motivation to study STEM topics. With the nation's continuing shortage of scientists and engineers, there is an urgent need for diverse students who enter and complete STEM education at all levels. The project activities include development and delivery of integrated STEM modules that connect locally and culturally relevant materials with the Smithsonian's Mi Tierra-Mi Mundo interactive role play exploratory game and professional training that scaffolds Mi-Tierra-Mi Mundo and STEM modules to present in traditional STEM settings. The project will use a longitudinal mixed methods randomized control trial research design to determine what aspects of the intervention affect the differential participation and success rates of students from underrepresented groups.

The proposed project has two unique and important features. First, it aims to enhance knowledge and develop dispositions for STEM among Latino students in the context of integrated STEM content and activities. Second, the project will introduce innovative technology-based simulations of real-world situations that engage Latino students to address STEM issues related to local watershed problems. These strategies can be adapted for other STEM areas and teacher education programs. Prototype activities are adaptable to a variety of teacher professional development efforts, and the proposed technologies for implementing and teaching simulations will be widely available for use in the classroom and outreach settings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hispanics are underrepresented in scientific, technical, engineering and mathematics (STEM) fields in proportion to their numbers in the US population. There is an urgent need for Hispanics to enter and complete STEM education at all levels to achieve greater equity among the US population and also to fulfill US STEM workforce needs. The BPR project aims to implement STEM learning modules that contain culturally relevant content and immersive technologies to middle school students. The project was housed within the Cyber-ShARE Center for Excellence at UTEP.

The investigators developed modules around topics that focus on assessment of water pollution and potability; improvement of water potability by filtering pollution; refinement and improvement of water pollution assessment to ensure safe potability; and integration of the three topics into a unified capstone project that helps the students solidify their understanding of STEM-integrated learning and scaffold the concepts and methods learned.

The connection of appropriate math, science, engineering, and technology activities incorporated lessons learned from the Smithsonian Latino Center’s (SLC) pilot virtual role-playing adventure game called Mi Tierra-Mi Mundo/My Land-My World in which students learn about and apply real-world ecological concepts related to sustainability and stewardship. The primary emphasis of the modules is to make connections that leverage the students’ experiences of the virtual role-playing game and build upon the students’ learning about real-world ecological concepts related to sustainability and stewardship. In the last year of the grant, the investigators launched the Sol y Agua learning platform that is inspired by the Mi Tierra-Mi Mundo game. The aim of Sol y Agua and its associated modules is to integrate culturally-relevant and interdisciplinary computer science and computational thinking content into middle-school curriculum. Its development has been supported by the BPR grant, a partnership with the SLC, and a partnership with Google through their CS4HS program. The platform and associated activities are aligned with  the State of Texas standards in mathematics, science.  

Teacher training on the modules integrate learning theories (e.g., problem-based, constructivism and others) and include innovative educational technologies. Selected modules will be published on the CyberShARE website and Google’s educational website.

Intellectual Merit. The project identified that culturally relevant immersive experiences for STEM education conducted in engaging, informal learning settings can provide a linkage between the STEM concepts studies by students in the formal classroom and the non-school experiences that students find personally meaningful. The project found that culturally relevant immersive experiences that highlight communication and provide corresponding verbal explanations in student-friendly environments encourage students to become interested in learning about STEM. The explorations provided by the STEM and Sol y Agua modules are designed to help students in the techniques of making observations of scientific processes and to provide culturally relevant examples of science and mathematics. Overall, the project revealed that culturally relevant immersive experiences depend on conceptual understandings and hands-on observation of simple and relatable learning opportunities that helped students to build an understanding of scientific and mathematical processes and concepts. It is in the “doing” rather than the “seeing” of STEM that the curriculum developer made to instill in others and communicate a love of the scientific discipline and a sense of appreciation toward STEM advancement. A focus of the curriculum is to engage students in hands-on activities, problem solving exercises, and collaborative group work. With a goal of instilling environmental stewardship via constructivist instructional methods, the result in this project increased awareness and understanding of STEM concepts.

Broader Impacts. The project indicated that beyond the traditional classroom curriculum, there are opportunities for out-of-classroom settings such as parks, museums, oceans, and space centers, to all be utilized as meaningful and engaging settings for contextualizing and connecting STEM curriculum content to the real life, non-school experiences of students. The work in immersive education includes key innovative strategies to reach a diverse core of audiences, in particular under-resourced communities through targeted outreach activities that include development of bilingual resources and key partnerships with community organizations to ensure the project's sustainability.   

Outcomes. Based on the results of the project, the investigators recommend STEM education researchers and practitioners to: (a) invite field-based science professionals to serve as informal educators delivering content specialized based upon their professional occupations, (b) design learning modules that utilize engaging, non-classroom learning environments that contextualize concepts for students, and (c) foster collaboration between formal school teachers and compatible informal STEM educators. The Sol y Agua student team participated in several conferences to present their work on the design and development of an educational game. The team won first place for a video addressing a topic of the game (i.e., data visualization) at the 2017 AAAS Emerging Researchers National (ERN) Conference. In addition, Christian Murga won first place in the undergraduate poster section for his poster that demonstrated the importance of data visualization and how this topic was incorporated within the game.
